questions.text: A patient presents with mild, localised, painless redness of both eyes for a day, as shown below. It blanches on application of 2.5% phenylephrine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical vignette is episcleritis.

  • Episcleritis presents as an acute onset of mild, localised redness and is usually bilateral.
  • It is a benign, self-limiting inflammation of the superficial episcleral plexus. It is more common in middle-aged females and is usually idiopathic.
  • It presents with sectoral or diffuse redness without significant pain, visual loss, or discharge.
  • The vessels in episcleritis are radial and blanch with phenylephrine 2.5%. Symptoms like photophobia and foreign body sensation may be present, but are mild.

Explanation of other options:

Bulbar spring catarrh (Option A): A chronic allergic condition (vernal keratoconjunctivitis) more common in young males with intense itching, gelatinous limbal thickening (Horner trantas dots), and giant papillae.

Pterygium (Option C): Presents as a fibrovascular growth from the conjunctiva encroaching onto the cornea; it appears as a fleshy, triangular tissue rather than diffuse redness and is not typically bilateral

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis (Option D): A hypersensitivity reaction to bacterial antigens, especially TB or staphylococcal antigen and presents with small, white, nodular lesions near the limbus with surrounding congestion.

questions.text: What is the thickness of the sclera at the insertion of the recti muscles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sclera is thinnest at the insertion of the recti muscles and is around 0.3 mm.

  • The sclera is the dense fibrous outer coat of the eyeball, composed mainly of collagen and elastic tissue, continuous anteriorly with the cornea and posteriorly with the optic nerve sheath.
  • It is around 0.3 mm thick at the insertion of the recti muscles and6 mm elsewhere (Options B, C, and D ruled out).
  • The sclera contains dense, irregular collagen bundles that are 10-16 μm thick and 100-140 μm wide. This irregularity and higher water content explain why the sclera is opaque, unlike the transparent cornea.
  • Sclera provides structural integrity, maintaining the shape of the eye and helping preserve constant intraocular pressure during eye movements.

Layers and Associated Structures of Sclera:

  • Episclera: A thin, vascularized connective tissue layer covering the sclera, rich in vessels and lying beneath the conjunctiva.
  • Lamina fusca: A brownish pigmented inner layer adjacent to the uveal tract (choroid), forming the outermost layer of the suprachoroidal space.
  • Lamina cribrosa: A mesh-like region at the posterior pole through which optic nerve fibres pass.

questions.text: Which structure becomes visible when the sclera is thinned out?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thinning of the sclera reveals the underlying pigmented uveal tissue.

  • The sclera, being opaque and collagen-rich, normally conceals the deeper structures. However, when it becomes thinned out, which is seen in conditions like scleromalacia, the underlying uveal tissue becomes visible as a bluish or dark hue, due to the pigmented nature of the choroid, a component of the uveal tract.
  • Blue sclera can also be seen in other conditions which cause thinning of the sclera, such as connective tissue disorders like osteogenesis imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS). It is also seen in buphthalmos.
  • Rare causes of blue sclera include syndromic conditions such as Marshall-Smith syndrome (characterized by accelerated prenatal skeletal growth), Russell-Silver syndrome (associated with short stature and dysmorphic features), and Hallermann-Streiff-François syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Cornea(Option A): Not anatomically behind the sclera. It is continuous with the sclera anteriorly, not beneath it.

Iris (Option B): Lies anterior to the lens and behind the cornea, not beneath the sclera.

Retina (Option D): Located behind the uveal tract and not immediately beneath the sclera.

questions.text: What is the commonest cause of posterior staphyloma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common cause of posterior staphyloma is high or pathological myopia.

  • Scleral stretching can occur due to various conditions and is termed ectasia when only the sclera is involved, and when both the sclera and underlying uveal tissue are involved, it is referred to as a staphyloma.
  • Posterior staphyloma refers to an outpouching of the weakened posterior sclera, and it is most commonly seen in patients with pathological (high) myopia.
  • The following image shows a posterior staphyloma on B-scan ultrasonography.

Explanation of other options:

Glaucoma (Option A): Usually arises due to the anterior segment pathology and affects the optic nerve head.

Retinal detachment (Option B): Also a complication of high myopia, but it does not cause posterior staphyloma.

Iridocyclitis (Option C): Inflammation of the anterior uveal tract and presenting with pain and red eye.

questions.text: The sclera is pierced by all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sclera is pierced by the optic nerve, which instead exits the eye posteriorly through the lamina cribrosa.

The sclera is pierced:

  • Anteriorly (about 4 mm behind the limbus): by anterior ciliary arteries and veins. (Option A ruled out)
  • Near the equator: by vortex veins (Option B ruled out)
  • Posteriorly around the optic nerve: by short and long posterior ciliary arteries and nerves. (Option C ruled out)

The optic nerve itself exits posteriorly through the posterior scleral foramen, a specialised opening which forms the lamina cribrosa.

Explanation:

The treatment of scleritis includes NSAIDs, systemic or local corticosteroids, and antibiotics in cases of infectious scleritis.

  • Scleritis is a severe, potentially vision-threatening inflammation of the scleral tissue, commonly associated with systemic autoimmune diseases, most commonly rheumatoid arthritis.. It can also arise secondary to infection.
  • Immune-mediated scleritis can be either anterior or posterior. Anterior scleritis is further divided into:
    • Non-necrotising types: diffuse or nodular
    • Necrotising with active inflammation
    • Necrotising without inflammation
  • Scleromalacia perforans is a type of anterior scleritis (necrotising without inflammation) associated with rheumatoid arthritis and is shown below.
  • Other commonly associated autoimmune conditions are Wegener's granulomatosis, polyarteritis nodosa, and Crohn's disease.
  • Symptoms include severe, boring ocular pain, radiating to the face, jaw, or temple due to trigeminal nerve involvement. It can also cause photophobia.

Management depends on the severity and underlying cause:

  • NSAIDs are typically used in mild or non-necrotising anterior scleritis, especially in idiopathic cases.
  • Steroids are the mainstay in more severe, necrotising, or posterior scleritis, or when NSAIDs are ineffective.
  • Antibiotics are used to treat infectious scleritis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a sudden onset of painful loss of vision and watering of eyes.. On gonioscopy, the angle structures are evaluated, and a prominent anatomical landmark is identified between the trabecular meshwork and the ciliary body. Which of the following best describes the significance of this structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The scleral spur is the structure identified on gonioscopy between the trabecular meshwork and the ciliary body, and it serves as the origin of the longitudinal fibres of the ciliary muscle.

  • The scleral spur is the anterior-most projection of scleral tissue seen on gonioscopy at the angle of the anterior chamber.
  • It serves as the anatomical junction between the trabecular meshwork anteriorly and the ciliary body posteriorly. Importantly, it acts as the attachment site for the longitudinal fibres of the ciliary muscle, which facilitate aqueous humour outflow through Schlemm's canal.

Explanation of other options:

It forms part of the optic disc (Option A): lies in the posterior segment of the eye and has no anatomical relationship with the scleral spur

Aqueous humour production (Option C): It is done by the ciliary body.

Contraction leads to relaxation of zonules (Option D): Contraction of ciliary muscles leads to relaxation of zonules.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about ciliary staphyloma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All listed statements accurately describe ciliary staphyloma.

  • Scleral stretching is known as ectasia when it involves only the scleral tissue. Staphyloma is used to describe scleral protrusion when it includes the underlying uveal tissue along with it.
  • Ciliary staphyloma refers to an ectatic protrusion of the sclera located in the ciliary zone, which is defined as the region extending up to 8 mm posterior to the limbus (Option A).
  • This condition is characterised by the incarceration of the ciliary body (Option B) into the thinned-out sclera, and the ectatic area typically appears bluish and lobulated (Option C) due to the underlying uveal tissue and scarring.
  • It may occur as a complication of scleritis, glaucoma, or ocular trauma.

The image below shows an anterior staphyloma.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the OPD as shown below. Identify the false statement regarding the condition.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a limbal dermoid, which is lined by stratified columnar epithelium.

  • A limbal dermoid is a congenital benign tumour classified as a choristoma, meaning it contains histologically normal tissue in an abnormal location.
  • It typically presents in early childhood as a yellowish, soft, subconjunctival mass most commonly located at the inferotemporal limbus, often with hair follicles or other dermal components.
  • Histologically, the lesion is composed of collagenous tissue and dermal elements covered by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Limbal dermoids are often associated with systemic syndromes such as Goldenhar syndrome and Treacher Collins syndrome.
  • Goldenhar syndrome (Oculoauriculovertebral Spectrum): Arises due to abnormal development of the first and second branchial arches. Other ocular associations include upper eyelid coloboma, optic disc coloboma, and microphthalmos.
  • Treacher Collins Syndrome (Mandibulofacial Dysostosis): A genetic disorder affecting the first and second branchial arch derivatives. Ocular features include lower eyelid coloboma, slanted palpebral fissures, cataract, microphthalmos, and lacrimal system anomalies.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presented to you with a complaint of a red right eye. He was initially diagnosed with episcleritis and started on topical steroids. He then developed pain waking him from sleep, along with proptosis and restriction in eye movements. An orbital pathology was suspected, and a CT was ordered, demonstrating increased choroidal thickening of the right eye, and his B-scan is as shown below. What is the correct statement about this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis based on the given clinical vignette and B-scan ultrasonography showing the classic T-sign is posterior scleritis.

  • Posterior scleritis is a severe inflammatory condition that affects the posterior part of the sclera and often goes undiagnosed due to its deep anatomical location and nonspecific symptoms.
  • It can present with pain severe enough to wake patients from sleep, mild proptosis ptosis, restriction of extraocular movements, and may mimic orbital or choroidal masses.
  • B-scan ultrasonography is crucial for diagnosis and often reveals the classic "T-sign," which represents fluid in the sub-Tenon space forming a "T" shape with the optic nerve shadow.

Explanation of other options:

Severe anterior scleritis (Option A): Anterior scleritis, while painful, does not typically cause proptosis, extraocular movement restriction, or the characteristic T-sign on B-scan.

The age of onset is greater than 50 (Option C): The age of onset of posterior scleritis is usually less than 40 years.

Surgery should be planned (Option D): Surgery has no role in the management of posterior scleritis.
